moves.3. Nf3 Nd7: Black challenges me to take advantage of his passiveness.
moves.4... h6 5. h4 b6: Good, this diagonal is always hard to control.
moves.6. e4 Bb7 7. Nbd2 Ne7: Black should have taken its chance to go e5.
moves.8. Bg3 a6: Another passive move. It's up to me.
moves.9. Bd3: Nothing drastic, but g6 is a target.
moves.9... g6 10. h5: I know this will block the wing, but I had faith in a slower undermine of black's kingside.
moves.10... Bg7: Fortunately, my opponent didnt take the chance, and played this sensible move.
moves.11. g5: My thoughts were: "anything in order to allow my queen to come out on the kingside."
moves.11... hxg5 12. Nxg5: Now, the black shield is strangely weak. But I made a sac here...
moves.12... Bxd4: It's ok, I have to tempt him wiht something in order to allow me build the attack.
moves.13... f5: ? Nf8 would have been enough, or Rf8. White has already the edge, but this is awful.
moves.14. Nxe6 Qc8: I could win the bishop, but I wanted to go on with the attack instead... and I almost lost!
moves.15. O-O-O Ne5 16. Bxe5 Bxe5: He has saved his bishop, and material is even. Now I have to show that I did it wisely.
moves.17. hxg6: Losing a piece, but with a stunning attack.
moves.17... Rxh1 18. Rxh1 Qxe6 19. Rh6: Rh8 is impossible, but this is not bad, too...
moves.19... Qxa2: This can hardly be a problem, but I handled it too optimistically.
moves.20. Qh5 Qxb2+ 21. Kd1: Black can go on with another check, then... nothing.
moves.21... Kd7 22. exf5: The two joined pawns are a powerful force, but it is hard to see how to exploit it.
moves.23... Re8: Wiser than it seems at first sight.
moves.24. Ne4: ? Qg4 posed a hard to meet treat. The knight ought himself to the king's guard.
moves.24... d5 25. Ng5: I realized Qg4, but it was too late now.
moves.25... Qb1+ 26. Kd2 Bc3+: Black hopes to deflect my king to avoid more threats on the kingside.
moves.27. Kxc3 d4+: Nothing to do. I won't bite it, and give you some chances.
moves.28. Kd2 Qb4+ 29. Kd1: I realized black had perpetual check, unless I dare to move my king into a dangerous journey on the kingside... with blakc's lsb looking freely at it...
moves.29... Kc8: Unpinning the knight, black threats mate. The last chance...
moves.30. Rh8: The more powerful and unexpected way to cope with the thread.
moves.30... Ng8: A very smart move, trheatening mate...
moves.31. Ne6: And the activation of the knight as "umbrella". Black can try the perpetual once more.
moves.31... Bc6: Black activates the bishop, covers the Re8, and tries to add power and coordination to his pieces. Here, Qh7 was decisive... unless black's perspectives of perpetual check.
moves.32. Bxa6+: This seems to be very clever. it isn't.
moves.32... Kb8 33. Qh7: At last, but better was one move before.
moves.33... Bf3+: This is another "coup of scene" I should have foreseen. Am I busted?
moves.34. Kc1 Qa3+ 35. Kd2 Qc3+ 36. Kc1 Be4: I have to pay for my overconfidence. With a piece.
moves.37. Qxc7+ Qxc7 38. Nxc7 Kxc7: Now, I should save my pawns, with Bd3, but it will be a lost fight.
moves.39. Bc4: If I recover the piece... a drawn is still possible.
moves.39... Nf6 40. g7: The pawn is now on the seventh rank. Look what interesting tactic comes here...
moves.40... Bxf5 41. Rxe8: Black' can't take the rook, or my pawn queens. The game is technically won.
